.... second happiest day is the day they sell it. ;-D

I'm kind of enjoying the cadence of a nightly big protest, speeches, 9 minutes of silence on a bridge in portland, then more speeches... then the crowd things, the police get upset that somebody touches their fence and attack everybody. Last night they started using this LRAD sound weapon. There's actually no pretense that the protesters doing anything beyond shaking the fence, throwing empty water bottles, and graffiti. It's kind of sadly ironic, if the police stopped attacking people then people might not be so sure they need reform.
Solid first post!
That's a wonderful offer.... here's [some pictures](%gZj+rR76yPn42ocxcuArOAoOVY7QJNa/85Af9asZGTw=.sha256) of my protest from a few days ago... been going every night.

This is a tricky problem and something we've had to deal with [@Planetary](@oeNoy1RIArVdMdk8ndeoKbAKuU8b56VgxlYP5y8b9Ic=.ed25519) as well. What we did was hook up zendesk sdk for reporting posts. Every message can be reported regardless if they came through our pub.  From zendesk we can add hashes to a block list on a server which our pub's check so they stop relaying that feed if that's what we want. In terms of the app, we process the feed then put it in a sqlite database. There's a check system to find which content has been labeled objectionable and blocked. We were hoping to get #gabbygrove working but haven't been able to get full support so we're using the legacy feed format . We felt Apple's rules are about being able to see the content in the app instead of if it exists in the database somewhere. 

I'll cc [@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519) and [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) who've been doing this work.  Getting type:delete and type:edit i think are important because it's much better for people to delete / edit things from their own feed than to have some service do it. 

We're not done with getting all of the planetary system working, and can't put in the app store til it's all working. We've not yet had any content which we had to block, flag, or delete. 

I don't know how to explain to apple that you're not controlling things if you run pub's. [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519)'s option of going towards DHT invites, rooms, and no pubs as a service totally works, but i think we'll lose users in the on boarding process.

[@rchaves](@VUgbo/ihmVWgh7szFJcG0Tg395T5/8JU0jijEVmyByU=.ed25519)

Hey, we'd be happy to share / collaborate on the blocking service.. i could see us having different policies but there's no reason to duplicate effort... we could figure out how to have something blocked in feedless and not planetary or vice versa... i know we'd benefit from being able to direct people to a web interface... 

I see this as something where everybody making ssb apps wins if we can get the protocol to get more adoption and users.

[@adria0](@ZFWw+UclcUgYi081/C8lhgH+KQ9s7YJRoOYGnzxW/JQ=.ed25519)

Hey, were you the person at 36c3 who was talking about creating an archive database to make like a search engine backup for activist websites that was p2p? I'm wanting an ssb search engine / backend for planetary... i thought your stuff might work, but i might be confused.
Yeah, i'm struggling with how many games there are in this bundle...  It'll take weeks to just download and try each one, and who has time with that with all the protesting.

What's the state of #patchql? We're running a version of ssb-viewer at planetary.link, which is fine, but it's pretty limited. I was thinking it'd be cool to have a slick react front end to it.  I saw [@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519) did a [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lVqUSi9XxnE) a couple weeks ago, but the [code](https://github.com/sunrise-choir/ssb-patchql) hasn't been updated in 4 months. Where it at? Maybe  [@Piet](@U5GvOKP/YUza9k53DSXxT0mk3PIrnyAmessvNfZl5E0=.ed25519) or [@mikey](@6ilZq3kN0F+dXFHAPjAwMm87JEb/VdB+LC9eIMW3sa0=.ed25519) knows?

Here's some of what we're thinking of in terms of design for planetary.link. The stuff being done with feedless.social is super interesting, but building a UI like this would be easier with react.  I'm not quite sure how to handle keys with reading / login when we don't store them on the sever... but seems like a worthy goal. 

![Desktop.png](&hLvDl26Wq0sfOCDsT7K1f73Lkg/ZmRCmAX2zFktZ3hQ=.sha256)
![Desktop Search.png](&VLdT9jpeZOPNQYqyrdN4qrKdzVQiAqAOg9ZRcDdk8LU=.sha256)

Planetary's business model is pretty the same as [new vector](https://vector.im/) which builds and maintains [riot.im](https://riot.im) and does services and hosting for companies or governments who want to use matrix. 

We'll do hosted service for multi-user publishers who want to publish content on ssb where we manage and keep their keys safe. We'll do payment processing and content gateways for people who want to charge access to join their private groups, for member only / subscription content. For individual users, we'll provide cloud hosting of content, similar to how you can view instagram on the web and how you use dropbox / google cloud / icloud for back up of content so it's not all on your phone. Probably helping folks make pretty website around their ssb content the way facebook pages / wordpress / etc work.

It's been talked about in the past plenty but i'm happy to answer any questions.

Hey [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) it's something I noticed recently, the code is simply an installation of the [code on ssbc](https://github.com/ssbc/ssb-viewer). But you're right, i did modify the code to change the link back to Planetary, you can find the modifications [here](https://planetary.link/.well-known/ssb-viewer.tar.gz). 

[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) and I noticed that it wasn't honoring the publicHosting flag. But we aren't able to find the code running at [viewer.,scuttlebot.io](viewer.,scuttlebot.io), so it's clearly also in violation of the AGPL.  

I'm not a member of ssbc so i can't fix the released code, but you should definitely go find out who's running viewer.scuttlebot.io in complete and flagrant violation of the AGPL. ;-D
yeah, somebody should update the github version. ;-D

[@okdistribute](@hCDeKTwEhhhNXtg00adkMDi+tx6qrRApFFj49QBM3lY=.ed25519) 

I heard through the grapevine that there's going to be some report on security / privacy and secure scuttlebutt coming to decentpatterns.xyz? I'm guessing it's negative since there are some real security and privacy problems with ssb. 

I'm curious to learn more.

-rabble

[@Piet](@U5GvOKP/YUza9k53DSXxT0mk3PIrnyAmessvNfZl5E0=.ed25519) do you think a ssb-viewer update could be built on it? run it on a sever, present graphql... it'd of course not support posting and shouldn't share private messages. 

ps, [@cel](@f/6sQ6d2CMxRUhLpspgGIulDxDCwYD7DzFzPNr7u5AU=.ed25519)  & [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) I've pulled in the code from git-ssb, posted it in public on the planetary [github repo](https://github.com/planetary-social/ssb-viewer), and am working on getting the publicwebhosting flag respected. Thanks for pointing out the source. 

I think this just again shows the need for private groups and also the various implementations to not pass on requested data if the requester is not within a few degrees of separation from the feed being requested. If bad stuff can happen with old code and misconfigured servers, just imagine malicious actors.

I must be confused, because the name of the project sounded so similar to solar. it was a decentralized cloud back up system made for activists so we didn't lose movement websites. 

I hate it when i forget to bookmark things. ;-D

There's only so much you can do, but this is what we did for our [privacy policy](https://planetarysupport.zendesk.com/hc/en-us/categories/360002326834-Rules-Policies). 

In terms of longer term work, i think the real solution is to create a commons model of governance so communities of people could enact these things instead of the service provider.  

GabbyGrove works, and has implementations in go and node for ssb, but the plugins don't all work and the main ssb apps like manyverse, patchwork, patchbay don't support it. I think oasis  might and of course planetary does.  We just had to get planetary out there and couldn't wait for everybody to slowly adopt it. If you helped push it i think it'd help a lot. Nobody's objecting to it just because not prioritizing the work. 

Personally i'm most excited about earthstar because that lets us do multiple devices, delete, ephemeral content, etc...

Welcome [@Ari Rodriguez](@yoZN+y/crk4Gvb4bJ48QIUAhMXlJFaYFiAddc7oItww=.ed25519) it's great to have more folks in the community with deep crypto knowledge. I noticed you did some shamir secret sharing, we've had an ssb project which worked on that for key backup, #dark-crystal.

The delete we're talking about is a soft delete, where you leave the content on the feed and in your replicated databases but you don't display it to the user because the author has requested it. With #gabbygrove you can do a stronger delete where you actually stop hosting the content and replicating it, because it's signed by not embedded in the log.

Last year [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) add the ability to actually remove all the feed content when you block somebody, so you're not longer keeping a copy of content from somebody you blocked. That's not quite the same thing as delete. 

There are proposals like [@cinnamon](@fBS90Djngwl/SlCh/20G7piSC064Qz2hBBxbfnbyM+Y=.ed25519)'s #earthstar which is similar to but not ssb which would allow for proper ephemeral content and delete. Again, even then it doesn't prevent anybody from keeping a copy of the data around.

So we're close to having it working in [@Planetary](@oeNoy1RIArVdMdk8ndeoKbAKuU8b56VgxlYP5y8b9Ic=.ed25519) but we were using the "type": "dropContentRequest" and "hash":  "%2LM6gN66H/wyw7TcQmkw9kECTZVjyDo66B99TjS16VU=.sha256" format. 

I'm going to poke around today and see if i can't get support for your delete message type in to planetary.

I think we might want to ask [@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519) / [@cryPhone📱](@uOReuhnb9+mPi5RnTbKMKRr3r87cK+aOg8lFXV/SBPU=.ed25519) as he's the person who developed it and chose that message type.
This might be a dumb question, but is it in English?

Getting private groups is so huge! Thanks [@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519), [@keks](@YXkE3TikkY4GFMX3lzXUllRkNTbj5E+604AkaO1xbz8=.ed25519), [@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519), [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519), and everyone else who's been doing the heavy lifting work to make this happen.
[@Raydegroat](@AMlISFSCmpphzoC9wOaMOvvnNW8BB0I+9ri4vG5Qz54=.ed25519) it tastes great!

I've been thinking about how to show users some examples of interesting content on scuttlebutt to help them find their community and provide and example of how to use the app. My feeling is that we model our behavior in a space off of what we see. So to communicate culture we've got to show it to people. 

I was having people autofollow [@The Weekly](@iVPi/B73hJSpsUB8XbSnlxe3NembPXLjOfIexlYdgJA=.ed25519) but [@masukomi](@LzTjF5eAVC6xprPMGeNzqEP/EEBIGpM6hDaaY10hrz8=.ed25519) isn't updating it any more. We also are auto following [@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519)'s [@Current Events](@wNmXqk80DL4FrBjzZcYqbKs/SpsPv6MVX6BLICabPfI=.ed25519), the [@Planetary](@oeNoy1RIArVdMdk8ndeoKbAKuU8b56VgxlYP5y8b9Ic=.ed25519), and myself. This was a somewhat random choice of content. 

But as we get close it'd be cool to actually pick some things. So any ideas of some good feeds which might show off a breadth of interesting things in the scuttleverse?

[@andrestaltz_phone](@+UMKhpbzXAII+2/7ZlsgkJwIsxdfeFi36Z5Rk1gCfY0=.ed25519) You mean the quotes on the site about manyverse? Those are cool, but that's not what i'm asking. 

I'm looking for ideas of people / feeds who would like to opt-in to having their content shown in our explore tab, it's similar to extended network in patchwork. Interesting people or content which highlights the scuttleverse.

[@cblgh](@C6fAmdXgqTDbmZGAohUaYuyKdz3m6GBoLLtml3fUn+o=.ed25519) explore is really popular and widely used on instagram and twitter. I find it useful on patchwork and oasis, it's more interesting actually because it's friends of friends. 

Patchwork does suggested followers which is an interesting idea, it's also common feature on twitter/instagram/facebook. 

Peer invites seem cool, but the process of finding a friend, generating the invite, getting it from them, putting it in the right spot will lose a lot of people. That's why folks use the same account name on various services, just "I'm rabble on twitter or Instagram" is something you can tell a person. Even something like, follow me on scuttlebutt, i'm "@THUzexG1y6kWofwiN8Lix/jNH/P6roYdlCDgpAn2HSc=.ed25519" isn't going to work. Once i saw somebody post a slide deck with their ssb ident but i wasn't able to copy it correctly. Something like [WebFinger](https://webfinger.net/) that the fediverse uses is better, you give somebody a domain or email and they can present all of your identities on various services. 

I've been using SSB for a few years now and often struggle with invites. I use patchwork, patchbay, oasis, planetary, ssb-cli, and manyverse. Of those i can't really tell you without searching or reading the docs how to generate an invite. I'm pretty sure manyverse has it, but i haven't been able to find it, haven't looked so hard, but i'm guessing DHT invites. I know how to do use pub invite, not peer, in patchwork. But i couldn't generate one for somebody to follow me.

What we have now is you install any ssb app and you get an empty screen with a kind of antisocial message saying go find your own way. The goal is to be bridged in to people's friends, but that's not what we do right now. What we do is bridged in to the center of a which ever pub happens to accept new users at the moment. 

My goal is to have a privacy preserving way of doing contact matching. A service, which can be run decentralized if we figure out how, where you can register your peer invites, or direct invites with a way of finding your device when you're online like over #tor, #yggdrasil, #i2p, rooms, or #cjdns. If somebody can show they are connected to me elsewhere then i let them get the invite from this service. 

But that's not what i'm asking here at all. What i want to know is there anybody who would want to opt-in to being being preloaded in the app as a example of what kind of community and posts people might expect to find on ssb. Right now we pre-filter with whatever random joined the pub you randomly choose at signup.

[@mixmix](@ye+QM09iPcDJD6YvQYjoQc7sLF/IFhmNbEqgdzQo3lQ=.ed25519)

Hey, i'm looking for some ssb accounts which make sense to pre-load but not not follow for planetary. My idea is we update them with each build for new users so they've got something on the extended network / explore tab. You've got a good mix of personal / photo / scuttlebutt content. 

Is it something you'd consider being ok with? My goal is provide examples of content, people to follow as a way of communicating more about the practices of communities on ssb. It's not something i'd want to do without consent of course. Thoughts?

Hey [@󠁪󠁯󠁥󠁹Joey](@BCM6DHYJvWzwWi1lFl2tjDXjaqyZAEmJH5ZONSpXhtc=.ed25519),

I'm not sure how closely you're following planetary. I really like your posts of food, your land, off grid stuff and tech... I'm looking for some good examples of ssb people to pre-load in to our explore tab on planetary. The idea is we'd make a script which downloaded your feed when we do a build, then we'd load it but not auto follow people. That way when they look on the explore tab they find examples of interesting people and content which they could choose to follow. If they  don't follow then the preloaded feed won't update.

Is this something you'd be ok with us doing, including your feed preloaded in to the app?

thanks,
rabble

Hey [@glyph](@HEqy940T6uB+T+d9Jaa58aNfRzLx9eRWqkZljBmnkmk=.ed25519)

I was wondering if you'd be willing to let us include your feed pre-loaded into planetary for new users to see when they go to the explore tab. They wouldn't be autofollowing you, but it would give people and example of how to use ssb and some insight in to the ssb ecosystem. I strongly feel that users model their behavior after what they see.

I like how you mix in personal, photos, fungi, and tech... Feels very much the essence of what the scuttleverse is. What do you think?

Oi [@Luandro](@2RNGJafZtMHzd76gyvqH6EJiK7kBnXeak5mBWzoO/iU=.ed25519)!

Espero que você esteja bem com a pandemia e sua família. I'm getting ready to launch planetary and i wanted to preload some ssb content in to our explore tab. To show what kind of things people are using ssb for and give folks an example of how to use scuttlebutt. What we do is pull the feed and store it in json and then load when a new user installs the app. They wouldn't be auto-subscribed but it would give people something to see and play when when they first install. If they like it they can follow you.

I wound't do it if you don't want, but i think you provide a really great perspective on many things which are the heart of the scuttlebutt project. What do you think?

Hey [@Angelica](@eANNuLfzX/9rlGODXHYV8WJb+zw2h+d7YsT4vpYPvD0=.ed25519)

I'm reaching out to people like yourself who really represent the values and practices of the scuttlebutt community. We're getting ready to open up planetary and we'd like to highlight some people in our explore tab. Our idea is to pre-load the feed in to the app so when people click on the explore tab there's interesting things to read and see. I think if we show behavior of how people use ssb then they'll take that on and start picking up on the communities values. 

We wouldn't auto-follow you, just give folks a chance to know you're there and see your work. Then they can follow if they want. If you don't feel comfortable of course we'd never include you without your consent. 

thanks,
rabble
Hey [@gwil](@PEqxT8YRvrkf2fyjAgTl8pmdo8aR4KVsKLyh0b5JyOE=.ed25519) yeah we've had lots of bugs. Do you mind trying it again?
[@Christian Bundy](@+oaWWDs8g73EZFUMfW37R/ULtFEjwKN/DczvdYihjbU=.ed25519) hey you might like brickshop.io? It's folks setting up tech and services for local activists.. ssb is on their roadmap.

We applied for Planetary as well. I was talking to them and they suggested in addition to the direct applications for funds it'd be possible for 'scuttlebutt' to apply for funds to re-grant to developers and projects outside of the normal flow of semi-annual CFP's.
yeh, did this get submitted and did we hear anything?

[@SoapDog](@gaQw6z30GpfsW9k8V5ED4pHrg8zmrqku24zTSAINhRg=.ed25519)

hey i'm looking for folks to pre-load their feed in to planetary for the discover tab... it doesn't auto follow them, but does provide some examples off ssb content for new users... you've got a nice mix of coffee pictures and coding posts... are you interested in having one of your feeds included?

Let's find ways to get more indieweb stuff in to ssb... we're using a viewer for planetary at planetary.link and i think that what i'd like is to build that viewer, either hosted on our servers or self hosted, to have more indie web features to bridge the two. 

I'd love to exploring working together but we're on a shoe string budget at the moment while we try and get planetary out the door and raise our seed round.

I keep looking at things like athena, roam, notion, and thinking that there could be a neat way of building something which was a mix of knowledgebase / wiki but also with some database driven apps. What i want is a rewrite of protest.net where you have some of the site being a collaborative knowledge base and some of it being a  more structured events listing. Kind of like what would be a mix of meetup and a wiki. 

Athena looks like it might be something which could be used this way. But it also could be done in a decentralized way building on earthstar type stuff.
Thanks so much. There is always such weird energy around this, it's a constant frustration. I appreciate your willingness  to be included as having a good example of how to use SSB helps so much.

These are some great questions [@haileycoop](@QdKPBH4vZne0DqD+v1mVJgeeOg8y3RxWuomT7pvIfEA=.ed25519). I want to thank you for asking in a way which helps figure things out and talk about them instead of generating more conflict.  I'm writing with the [@Planetary](@oeNoy1RIArVdMdk8ndeoKbAKuU8b56VgxlYP5y8b9Ic=.ed25519) identity but this is 

I think there are so many levels of governance to consider. There's the ssbc protocol level, lowest level, who decides what gets incorporated as standard. Then there is the affordances of the protocols and implementations which have governance through code as law. Then there are the front end apps which are promoted and which are used. They've got all sorts of power dynamics, norms, and rules built in to them. There aren't any closed source SSB apps that i know of, now that planetary is open source, but even then, who decides which PR's get merged, how well managed is forking if the creators aren't behaving. 

In terms of Planetary, it's a company with some investors. Their main power is in their ability to provide more money if needed, as they've not go any board seats for the company and the founding shares have 20x voting rights. It gives me in theory control similar to what zuckerberg has on facebook over the company. That power is only real if the economic side of the company works, ie there's enough money coming in to cover all the costs related to running and growing the business. 

There are a few commitments which i think keep planetary accountable. One is users own their identity and can move it off of the application if they want. You can download your data from centralized social media platforms, but you can't keep using them, you lose your relationships. Being able to switch apps and keep everything working is huge. If Planetary the company stops behaving well then you can leave. What's more, you can take the app and fork it. There's some services which would have to be setup around push notifications and the like so there is a cost, but it's possible unlike centralized systems.

Being a public benefit corp (not done but in progress) is another way of saying, the company will hold itself accountable and do a public audit of it's role in the world. 

The real solution is not so much constraints on planetary as a company, rather having a more vibrant community beyond the company building, maintaining, and supporting the ecosystem. 

Personally i'm quite keen on what [@cinnamon](@fBS90Djngwl/SlCh/20G7piSC064Qz2hBBxbfnbyM+Y=.ed25519) is doing with #earthstar and could see at some point in the future switching to using that as the default for planetary. It's purely speculative but that would be a big shift. If folks liked planetary focused on SSB and didn't want earthstar, i'd hope they'd take the code and keep maintaining that fork. 

I think the tricky part is how to balance out the few people who know enough and do enough work to shift the fundamentals with that power. How do we praise and value work being done, while communicating it's implications so various levels of user communities can be involved in co-designing the technology. We've got lots of informal power, which isn't necessarily bad, but needs to be acknowledged.

[@Ari Rodriguez](@yoZN+y/crk4Gvb4bJ48QIUAhMXlJFaYFiAddc7oItww=.ed25519) Have you see the work of [@Haskell Guy](@f5ABjSMAR95ajlGST63/xx+XUoty53mlSZZ3GhGbQeE=.ed25519)
and his [Haskell implementation of scuttlebutt?](https://git.sr.ht/~haskell-guy/ssb-haskell )

[@pat](@JUBGIPQ3KzZEqc03FX53bZucL9i/UqgHQgpPyJHPzpw=.ed25519), I'm pretty sure that won't happen. NZ has no plans to open up tourism to places that have any community transmission until there is a vaccine deployed locally. They are operating on a  mandatory 2 week quarantine system upon arrival. For now all 6500 spots are taken by citizens and residents and even then they're having to control the rate of people entering the country. Once there is capacity for citizens and permanent residents they'll open up to long term work visa holders and essential workers / essential industry support. For those people the government plan is to charger them the full cost of quarantine, around $10,000 NZD. 

There's between 100,000 and 200,000 residents and citizens who are currently overseas who the government expects to resettle back in NZ. They're adding capacity but carefully because there's been a few slip ups with infected arrivals leaving quarantine early. At current rate it'll take about a year just to handle returning citizens. 

There will be no international tourism to NZ until late 2021 or 2022.

[@cel](@f/6sQ6d2CMxRUhLpspgGIulDxDCwYD7DzFzPNr7u5AU=.ed25519) & [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) Just wanted to follow up. 

Thanks for the links, i've updated it so it respects the public web hosting flag and we're working on giving users an option in planetary to set it with the next release.
Or we could fix it so we're not hostile to users.

I think we need to rename block to 'mute' or something like 'disconnect' because it's not stopping them from seeing your stuff and it confuses people. I really like the idea of this, we need better ways of 'find us on ssb' where you're pulled in to a community who's invited you instead of a single follower. That it's a private group is much much better as it doesn't expose all the important meta data about the social graph without wanting to. 

> [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519): "While I am very excited about this idea, since private groups are private, I would take more time to carefully think about the privacy issues (IP address leakage) of using the DHT for this…"

The leaking of ip addresses worries me in general, i'd love a default way to open connections to people which wasn't ip address based. Be it tor, i2p, yggdrasill, cjdns...

[@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) I've heard problems with Tor in terms of battery performance on mobile but i think this is our best bet, there's a pure [js tor mplementation](https://github.com/Ayms/node-Tor). Connecting to a DHT to find an onion router address doesn't create nearly the privacy hole that an ip address would create.
I wish tactics like this would still work in the US. At this point the police would just start clipping wires or some right wing chud would just plow their cars in to the blockade.

Yeah, i've assumed for a while that we'd have rolling groups. Where when you needed to remove someone you had to roll the keys and re-invite. In the case of matrix rooms this rolling happens all the time.

They even have the signed messages transiting over a mesh peer to peer gossip network so the device you want to wipe never has to directly added to the internet, as long as it gets within mesh wifi distance of a device which has heard the delete order.

Doesn't the start of the quarantine seem like so long ago?

We've been using element for all of the twitter Blue Sky project and a few activist tech projects i've been involved with. There's some barriers to getting folks on board. 

What seems to work is to say "We've got a chat app which is like slack but with privacy and encryption. Go to element.io, create an account, and tell us what the account name is." Then we take that and invite them. Never once has somebody gotten the @username:matrix.org part right, they always just give the username part and we have to figure it out. Kind of makes usernames and federation tricky.

Once people get it installed and use it we're getting the same engagement as slack except that element doesn't do a good as job at notifications to draw people back in to the conversation.

Hey can we include your feeds in the preloaded feeds for Planetary?

I think we don't display tags right. You've got to click through to see them in patchwork, first we show show which tags a post has been given instead of a tags button. Then we also need the tags option to show a feed of taggings. So which tags have been added to what content by your network. If you have that it'd be super useful .

#### Gravatar like service for SSB?

What do folks think about a service which is like [gravatar](https://en.gravatar.com/) for scuttlebutt / earthstar identities? Obviously because gravatar is closed source we'd want to use something like [Libravatar](https://www.libravatar.org/) created for the fediverse.

As far as i can tell, the avatar services would work just as well for public ssb identities as they would for email addresses as they're both an md5 hash of a string. With both gravatar and libravatar you confirm your email or login with oauth/openid. The SSB way of doing that is either signing something with your private key or writing something to your log.

I think it'd be nice to optionally be able to get somebody's avatar and current about messages super quickly. Thoughts?

I'm not using manyverse day to day, so perhaps it's got ui around this, but in patchwork there's not easy way to  see the rooms broken out, with a list of people in the room. If we had that then we'd be able to see them and it'd really make sense out of them. That would then make it make sense to have hosted rooms.

Being able to setup hosted rooms is something we've considered doing as planetary.

Yeah, we wanted to make the pubs we run feel like transparent relays. But i think we went to far and do need to expose them in the pubs menu so it's clear they're out there allowing users to see it, unfollow, block, etc... 

Unless somebody makes a PR for it, i'll try and get that in to the next release myself.

[@cinnamon](@fBS90Djngwl/SlCh/20G7piSC064Qz2hBBxbfnbyM+Y=.ed25519) you're an inspiration to me and we're all incredibly lucky to share this time and space with you. Yeah, moving is a lot of work, but also the US just seems to be getting to be more of a nightmare. My personal plan is to go to Uruguay, where i used to live, for a while, and then on to New Zealand. Unfortunately although I have a residency class work visa it's not the same thing as residency and therefore i'm not on the list of people allowed to enter the country through the limited quarantine capacity. 

For folks working overseas, there's a few options, you could be a freelancer or even w2 employee in the US but live overseas, there are a few countries like Estonia, Georgia, and i believe Barbados who have specific remote worker covid visas. Another option is the DAFT visa to the Netherlands, which is pretty easy to get and would cover a lot of software developers. 

One thing worth remembering is that american companies pay software developers much more than any place else. I've often puzzled as to why, my guess is that it's probably due to a lot of the tech companies in the US being created by developers themselves and therefore prioritizing the field as valuable. Then other companies have to pay more to compete.

Reading [@Dominic](@EMovhfIrFk4NihAKnRNhrfRaqIhBv1Wj8pTxJNgvCCY=.ed25519)'s post about minimum wage i went and did some research...

So after taxes, a minimum wage worker in the US makes $13,900 USD. In New Zealand a full time minimum wage worker makes $21,610 USD. The Kiwi of course gets 4 weeks of vacation and health care with is never provided to an American worker who makes minimum wage.  The US system is actually setup so that you do get some welfare and support from the government if you make less than about $40k. It's perverse because for every dollar you make more than the minimum $13.9k they take away about one dollar in other services. There's little difference between making $15k and $35k if you're able to access all the services. 

Comparing cost of living, across the country as a whole, which we know is a bit tricky because prices vary a lot.

#### Indices Difference
* Consumer Prices in New Zealand are 0.98% higher than in United States
* Consumer Prices Including Rent in New Zealand are 5.98% lower than in United States
* Rent Prices in New Zealand are 19.34% lower than in United States
* Restaurant Prices in New Zealand are 6.60% lower than in United States
* Groceries Prices in New Zealand are 2.69% lower than in United States
* Local Purchasing Power in New Zealand is 20.53% lower than in United States

The only one which sticks out there is the PPP which i think is skewed because the US has way more people who make a ton of money, and more working poor. Where as in NZ has a narrower income distribution.

Average wealth is easy to skew if you have very wealthy people. If Bezos enters a room with 175 who have no money, then the average wealth of everybody in the room is $1 billion USD. 


What Dominic says about adjusting to the people around you in terms of spending really resonates with me.  It's really shifted how much i've spent and hasn't had a huge effect on my happiness or wellbeing. Knowing this hasn't made it easier to act on it.
Next build allows image / media attachments to replies. It's something patchwork, and i think manyverse have supported for a while.

That sucks, but as [@KawaiiPunk](@LVL4qjvmws3Cxavfi4iCQI6dSOqWqOyq5/5CHImILA8=.ed25519) says it looks like that's OC not CS. We've gotten very familiar with all the myriad of chemical weapons that the state has bee using on us. 

If you have this happen to you, there are sudecon wipes you can carry in your medical kit for protests which really help. Other than that water or saline solution is probably best. Once you get home cover every part of the body with dish soap. It's an oil and liquid dish soap breaks it down. I usually leave it on for 15 minutes, no rubbing, just keep it on. Be very careful as it'll be all over your clothes and anything you touch. No making out with comrades until everybody has been fully decontaminated and changed clothing!!!! Similarly be very careful if you need to use the bathroom after a potential exposure... you can guess why the burning would not be wanted.

After you've got soap over everything, take a cold or luke warm shower. Hot shower will open our pores and that's bad news. 

In Portland it's now normal for there to be OC, CS, and a few others to be spread in the are over many city blocks. 

Here's a picture of me getting a direct OC spray in the face, i had no idea it was coming and was not wearing any protection except prescription glasses. 

![Screen Shot 2020-10-05 at 6.56.17 PM.png](&BcZGAz1B2yzb3daZf9z+wRWTIJG0MHqvtNzBkEb3fpA=.sha256)

![Screen Shot 2020-10-07 at 11.18.51 AM.png](&Qe3qgXH+Bnv25mj2/0r+fPWgMKyOUfsZYyGwYnnGvU0=.sha256)
So sorry for your loss... i was devastated when my dad passed. I make a point of keeping talking to him, because it keeps him in my life even though i know he's passed.

content.text:
We've been looking at how to solve a couple issues with Planetary, with the hope that it'd be useful the rest of SSB around two issues.

How to map a user defined name to an identity. And how to do it in a decentralized way which is consistent with ssb's values of offline and local first. 

To do this we're thinking about webfinger and DID's to map identities to keys. This is similar to [@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519)'s ideas of using a room for it. You could have multiple labels for a single identity. One system falls back to a room being online, another to dns and a server. Neither are perfect.

But we found a step needed before we can do the webfinger -> DID mapping. We need to be able to authenticate to a web service using your SSB identity without an authentication server. Basically, using your ssb apps as the source of authority for logging in to services. 

To explore this we've been talking with Fission, a group of folks working on top of the ipfs ecosystem. They've got this thing called [UCAN decentralized authorization standard])(https://whitepaper.fission.codes/identity/id-overview). Seems like it'd be useful for making SSB identities things you can use to access other services. 


There's [a working session Wednesday 9pm PDT](https://talk.fission.codes/t/portable-usernames-dids-and-distributed-auth-with-ucan/1074) online where we'll work through how we might get the pieces to fit together. If this is interesting to other SSB folks it'd great to expand the conversation.
The mix of languages on these feeds is annoying. I think maybe we need to break out a different way of defining content vs people feeds.

[@andrestaltz](@QlCTpvY7p9ty2yOFrv1WU1AE88aoQc4Y7wYal7PFc+w=.ed25519) & [@rchaves](@VUgbo/ihmVWgh7szFJcG0Tg395T5/8JU0jijEVmyByU=.ed25519) what did you guys put in for your apple appstore [export compliance documentation](https://help.apple.com/app-store-connect/#/dev88f5c7bf9). I'm pretty sure that libsodium's crypto is export restricted.

Yeah. There is an [open letter and call to action](https://crimethinc.com/2020/08/22/open-letter-stand-with-anarchist-publishers-banned-by-facebook-announcing-a-solidarity-statement-from-anarchist-agency) going around.  I think it’s important to fight on this front but also, as you’d imagine being here, build autonomous alternatives.

My life these days is sitting at home all day working on [Planetary](@oeNoy1RIArVdMdk8ndeoKbAKuU8b56VgxlYP5y8b9Ic=.ed25519) and then going to protest every night. Yesterday there was a bunch of Trump supporters who showed up during the day and beat people up downtown. There was a large #BlackLivesMatter counter protest which chased them out of town. It’s so surreal code and protests when the outside world is so pretty.

Walking home from the #BlackLivesMatter protest I came across art celebrating the 100th anniversary of women winning the right to vote in the US. It’s worth reflecting that Seneca Falls, the founding of the women’s suffrage movement was in 1848. It took 70 years of struggle, direct action, and resistance to win the right to vote. Social change is a collective relay marathon.

Yesterday day I went to a protest demanding that PacifiCorp uphold their decade old agreement to remove dams on the #klamath river. The dams are killing the river ecology and salmon run. The movement against the dams is lead by the Yurok and Karuk tribes who live along the lower river. The company HQ is in Portland but the river itself is in Southern Oregon and Northern California where in grew up.

This summer I’ve been going to the #BlackLivesMatter protests with a speaker rig I built to play music, speeches, and counter announcements. A couple weeks ago the cops stole my gear and pepper sprayed me. I’m suing to get my stuff back, for damages, and to keep them from doing this to other people. 

Here’s an article [about the lawsuit](https://www.wweek.com/news/2020/09/04/in-legal-claim-protester-says-portland-police-stole-his-speakers-for-playing-the-national-anthem-during-arrests/), and one about [the music I’ve been playing](https://www.pdxmonthly.com/arts-and-culture/2020/09/rose-city-fm-the-sound-of-the-protests-in-portland). 

There are a [few](https://twitter.com/codywyattbzp/status/1301668618212528128?s=21)  [videos](https://twitter.com/soundblocpdx/status/1298088471043518465?s=21) about when I lost my gear. It’s pretty ironic because they took it just after I started playing the national anthem. 

After losing my speakers I had to buy new ones. It’s been fun being in the protest with something to do but the entire shift in American politics is scary.

As far as I know only [Planetary](@oeNoy1RIArVdMdk8ndeoKbAKuU8b56VgxlYP5y8b9Ic=.ed25519) does push notifications. We do it as silent notifications once a day to trigger syncing and also when the planetary pub sees follows, replies, and mentions. Those cause the app to sync in the background and when new content is discovered and downloaded the it displays a locally generated notification. 

There is no reason patchwork couldn’t do this too.

Planetary and the #scuttlebutt protocol we’re using is part of the emerging decentralized web (#dweb). It’s a bit ironic since the original web, [xanadu](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Project_Xanadu) was decentralized, and so is the [world wide web](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Wide_Web). What happened is as we went from a document focused system to using the web as an application platform first and then to a social application platform things shifted and the network effects concentrated value in centralized solutions. 


While our tech exists in parallel to the web we know that the browser stack (http/html/css/javascript) is the most powerful application development environment every created. Which is why I’m excited by the work nichoth is doing creating [ssb-web](%O4VMnUDfay7Hnk+3u8vazRjK3DS8ipIMgroTVwAMHsE=.sha256) in creating ssb backed websites. We need this bridge between the subjective commons managed #scuttleverse and the open web.

> [Mix Android](@G98XybiXD/amO9S/UyBKnWTWZnSKYS3YVB/5osSRHvY=.ed25519): Dig a deep hole. It's cooler underground?

I was going to suggest something like that. An RV or trailer is kind of terrible for that environment. What you want is thermal mass, which can reflect the heat and keep a temperature which is the average of day and night. A large overhanging shade structure over your trailer would help to I think. 

There are lots of amazing passive cooling systems. Done right you need no power and can be cool in very hot environments.

Okay. I wrote a dissertation. Here’s my #sourdough insight: I am definitely not a sourdough expert. But I can usually tell when a loaf is going to flop. Two loaves back I could just tell everything was wrong. It was too wet, wasn't coming together or rising at all. But I two spoonfuls of dough on the griddle just to make *something* and stuck the rest in the fridge.  The wonky dough made great biscuit-muffin-things, they were lovely fresh. So I kept cooking the dough like that instead of making a loaf. We had fresh biscuit-things all week. The next loaf was great. Same recipe and I'm not sure what I did differently.

Of course as I was pulling the A+ loaf out of the oven my neighbor texted to let me know that she'd left some of her reliably great bread on my porch. So we have a lot of great bread this week.

Early in my sourdough journey I took a lot of notes. I logged the measurements of every loaf, noted any substitutions, and evaluated the results. I tried a lot of different recipes, a few no-knead recipes, a few from [Sourdough](http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/930772319) by Sarah Owens. The book itself is growing on me. It was the wrong book to start with but I'm learning to appreciate all her non-bread recipes as great ways to use up starter.

I use the flour I can buy easily. Sometimes bulk from my grocery store, some King Arthur, some Bob's Red Mill. I was starting to branch out but then COVID-19 happened and now we definitely use what we can get. I usually use water that has boiled and sat out for a while, but there's almost always a kettle of just that on the stove. Once in a while I have to swat someone who is about to heat up my bread water to make coffee, but not if I wake up first.

I keep a 100% hydration starter fed with white flour. I usually add 50g water and 50g flour to 50g of starter.

Here are two recipes I've had good luck with (both adapted from Owen's book, though her recipes make more than we can eat in a week so these are 3/4 recipes):

Sourdough One
* 465g water
* 304g all purpose / bread flour
* 300g whole wheat flour
* 12g salt
* 120g starter

Sourdough Two
* 83g starter
* 105g oats or 10 grain hot cereal
* 375g water
* 34g honey or molasses
* 79g white flour (aka all purpose flour or bread flour)
* 334g whole wheat flour
* 8g salt

Mrs Green's Sourdough
* 590g white flour
* 150g whole wheat
* 560g water
* 160g starter
* some salt

I always bring my starter to room temperature and then feed it ~3 hours before I start the bread. If I plan ahead I definitly feed the starter twice before I start a loaf which leaves me with a lot of starter to use up. I'm not into throwing it away so I've been experimenting with cakes and pancakes with the discard.

For both recipes I combine everything but the starter and let it sit for ~45 minutes to autolyze. I don't know how necessary this is but I seem to have better luck when I don't skip this step. The [Tassajara Bread Book](http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1020430913) makes a very big deal about the importance of strething your grain by stirring in the same direction from the very beginning, which I do. The idea is that you're pulling from the edge into the center and not just stirring all willy-nilly. Again, this is very ingrained and I've always done it. I have not done any scientific testing.

I add the starter after 45 minutes and fold it in. Most recipes will tell you that you must use your hands for this. I don't, I use a big rubber spatula. YMMV.

This is where everything goes crazy. Sometimes I get to this step, cover the bowl with plastic (I have a silicone lid that I like.) and stick it in the fridge. Sometimes I cover it with plastic and leave it out overnight. Sometimes I leave it covered and come back to it every 90 minutes to "slap and fold" (which I sometimes do with the spatula and sometimes with wet hands. Wetting your hands definitely helps with sticking). Sometimes I stick it in the fridge overnight after a few hours of slap and fold. Sometimes I shape a loaf and then stick it in the fridge. Sometimes I shape a loaf and then let it rise for two hours. I do find that it needs to get to a place where it holds its shape a bit before I can reliably shape it.

Baking also happens in a few different ways. The notes on Sourdough Two say I bake it 30 min in a closed dutch oven, at 425° and then take the cover off for the last 10 min. If I'm using a dutch oven I definitely heat it in the oven for 15-20 min so it's as hot as the oven. Sometimes I line loaf pans with parchment and bake it in loaf pans. The dutch oven makes a nice crust. But some loaves seem to really need the support of the loaf pans.

I think what I'm trying to say is that a bread recipe is always going to want some adaptation. If you follow a recipe that works for other folks and you don't have a loaf that holds its shape at all, you probably need to work it more, either with a slap and fold or a dough hook or some kneading.

I do the last rise on parchment, so I don’t preheat it. If I’m using parchment I lift the dough into the dutch oven by the parchment, or line the loaf pan with parchment and do the last rise in the pan.

Got some questions about my ginger bug, so here’s what I know: ginger bug is a fermented soda starter.

My neighbor makes citrus soda with it that is really good. I've used her starter to make my own soda, but I always eventually let it die and then summer rolls around or I come into a lot of grapefruit and I miss it. I've read that you can start fermented soda from yogurt whey, but my last batch didn't work (possibly the culture wasn't active). It made a nice lemonade, but it never got really carbonated. So this time I'm following a real recipe to start my bug. In a large clean jar, I combined:

* 2 cups water
* 3T grated ginger
* 3T sugar

That's the starting point. Every day since then I've added **one tablespoon of ginger** and **one tablesoon of white sugar**. It's day 5 now and I'm getting some nice bubbles.

I stirred with a wooden spoon and covered with a cloth napkin and a rubber band. I didn't peel the ginger. I did boil the water and let it cool, which helps if your tap water is chlorinated.

I've read that honey or molasses work great and read that you must use white sugar. I've read that you should cover it with a coffee filter or muslin, and read that you definitely must seal the jar. I've read that you have to grate the ginger and read that it's fine to just slice it. I've read that you should never use a metal spoon and read that it doesn't matter. ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

But enough people swear by the method I’m using that I decided not to experiment too much.

Since the bug is starting to bubble, I started a soda today, too. I packed a jar of boiled and cooled water with lemon verbena leaves and added:

* ½c lemon juice
* ½c sugar
* ¼c ginger bug starter

I'll leave that out on the counter for a few days (covered) and when it starts to ferment I'll bottle it and let it sit at room temp for a few days, too.

I struggle on and off with insomnia. Sometimes it disappears for so long that I forget what to do about it. But here’s what I find  works. Passion flower tea with a few drops of skullcap tincture. B vitamins. [Mill River](https://lhasakarnak.com/products/mill-river-tea?variant=34160868941) tea, which is raspberry leaf, chamomile, peppermint, red clover, comfrey leaf, nettle, alfalfa, yarrow. A few drops of THC also helps, but that isn’t for everyone. FWIW, I only ever do one of those things, tea or THC.  Not both. And some herbs are fairly powerful so if you’re on any prescription meds double check for interaction.

I don’t usually fast on Yom Kippur, because I’m not Jewish, but it always seems weird to just eat while Noah is fasting. My compromise is that I don’t eat in front of him and I usually wind up skipping lunch.

This is one of my favorite cookbooks. I distinctly remember discovering Lukas Volger at a bar in Brooklyn that somewhat inexplicably had a Collection of cookbooks available to browse. They also served kombucha which I appreciated. I’m not opposed to alcohol (or I wouldn’t be fermenting hard cider.) But it’s still nice to be able to go out and choose between drinking something interesting that will get you tipsy and something interesting that wont. Anyway: they had a copy of Volger’s [veggie burgers every which way](http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/793893885) and it seemed like a lot of genuinely delicious recipes. I never did buy that one, but I’ve bought some of his other cookbooks, and they’re quite good. 

Which brings me to tonight’s dinner. It’s actually rice with fried tofu, roasted squash, mustard greens from the garden, and some avocado. For whatever reason the Thai basil in our garden is doing better than any other plant, so I made a sort of pesto black sesame and ThaI basil, and added some wasabi. The sauce wasn’t quite there, so I checked Bowl and realized it probably wanted a bit of rice vinegar and maybe a little bit of scallion. Soy sauce, mirin.  

What I’m saying is that this is a really good cookbook. And if you can’t live without meat there’s literally nothing in here you couldn’t add some delicious dead animals to. 🤷🏼‍♀️

I don’t, but I live in earthquake country and really should. We’re out of range of the wildfires, but not the smoke, so I’m definitely thinking a lot more about being ready to actually leave.  I feel like we’re prepared for earthquakes but that assumes we can stay put but won’t have buildings /water / power / stores for a while. We’re less prepared to evacuate without warning.

PS. The term “bug out bag” kind of irks me because it sounds paranoid. It is rational and responsible to be prepared for natural disasters, even when it doesn’t seem like the world is coming apart at the seams. Keeping our community whole after a disaster isn’t “bugging out”. Neither is ensuring that we can look out for ourselves so we can put energy and resources into mutual aid and community needs instead of focusing on our own survival. So I endorse finding better language for preparedness!

And I found a green potato in our groceries so I stuck it in water to let it develop some roots and moved it into a planter this week. We’ll see how it does. It’s in a planter with a tomato, which odd not supposed to be great, but I didn’t have anywhere else for it. 

My neighbor brought me some kale and broccoli seeds that she thinks will thrive in CA’s winter, so I’m getting organized to start those. I don’t have a great place for starting plants in my cottage, but I want more vegetables. 

I didn’t photograph my last turnip but someone is eating my turnip greens, and I would kind of like them to stop. Honestly not sure if it’s slugs or squirrels, but I’d rather not share my kale. #garden #gardening

### Letter from the Author/Editor
Thanks for reading the first issue, everyone! Feel free to talk to me about it in the comments, DMs, or even by DMing my main account, [@romeo](@LrIL+UAvV+msJFiCxKZMJHCDASB8ekaSefbH8qdEwKI=.ed25519). If you want to help contribute, let me know! If you really want something in here but it doesn't fit under the general guidelines, I'll make a section like "Community Submissions" or similar. So don't be shy! On a more personal note, I've found the biggest challenge so far is trying to actually read what I scroll through instead of only skimming to see if it would belong in the SPS (Scuttlebutt Post Summary). It definitely takes a level of mindfulness to consume the content and make that decision simultaneously. Despite that, I think I'm doing well! If the community got huge I would need help with running SPS, but at its current size and with what I can see of it, it takes about a half hour in the morning and evening to catch up and write entries for posts I want to include. And for me, that's manageable! Thanks again for reading, everyone, and if you don't leave feedback, I'll see you in about a week!

### Letter from the Author/Editor
Been thinking about this newsletter thing. Thought for a little bit about making a third account to follow everyone who could post something newsworthy. I've decided that this newsletter is not going to try to sum up the entire scuttleverse. This is heavily biased by my personal views and the people I choose to follow, and I'm okay with that. If you think I should put stuff in that I don't or vice versa, talk to me! If I don't change my mind, start your own post summary. I would love to see more of these reflecting other people's personal choices in what qualifies as newsworthy.

### Planetary Release 0.9.16 (Build 186)

We've pushed out a new release of [Planetary](https://planetary.social). Here are a few updates from [the changelog](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md). 

There's a but we're trying to track down where the app dies in the background. Once we get that fixed we'll be going through and inviting folks who signed up for our mailinglist. Feel free to invite friends now: [https://testflight.apple.com/join/M9hPo1gA](https://testflight.apple.com/join/M9hPo1gA)

We're looking at working on performance and reliability for the next release. We created a link which right now only works on phones with the app installed for https://planetary.social/p/@identity that takes you to a user. We're looking at a hosted viewer at that same url for folks who don't have the app installed. This is about making deep linking possible. Right now we don't let you do internal message links within the app, but it's on our roadmap to add as well.

**Added:**
- New Planetary typeface.
- Share your profile link to the world.
- Loading animation for Notifications and Channels screens.
**Fixed:**
- Show alert dialogs when errors occur.
- Report handled errors.



### [0.9.15] - 2020-03-26
**Fixed**
 - Post button not appearing when undocking the keyboard.
 - Crash when downloading logs in iPad.
 - Empty log when downloading logs.
 - Crash when database repair fails.
 - Bad wording for number of replies in a post.



### [0.9.14] - 2020-03-25
**Added**
 - Show spinning wheel when processing new messages.
**Fixed**
 - Issue with reply count different than replies shown.
 - Avatars when mentioning someone were displayed incorrectly sometimes.
 - Avatar disappearing when switching tabs.
 - Performance issues with Notification screen.



### [0.9.13] - 2020-03-20
**Fixed**
 - Login is now more efficient.
 - Posted hashtags are now compatible with other networks.
 - Fix hashtags with - sign in the middle.
 - Channels screen is sorted by newest to oldest.



### [0.9.12] - 2020-03-17
**Added**
 - Now you can open your profile tapping on your profile photo.
**Fixed**
 - Syncing is now more efficient.
 - Posted images are now compatible with other networks, like Patchwork.
 - Fix bug that prevented using the app after opening an image in full screen.

### [0.9.11] - 2020-03-10
**Added**
 - Redeem invitations: Do you want to follow a pub? Now you can now redeem invitations in Settings > Manage Pubs!
 - Switch to main net: The app now works in the main net, so expect to be prompted to logout and onboard again, otherwise the app won't work fine. Go to Settings > Advanced Settings and tap on Reset application and identity, or alternatively, go to Settings > Advanced Settings > Dangerous and powerful debug menu and tap on Logout and onboard.

**Fixed**
 - Performance improvements and minor bug fixes.

yeah, so planetary and scuttlebutt stores images, videos, audio and long posts as what we call [blobs](https://ssbc.github.io/scuttlebutt-protocol-guide/#blobs). They aren't sent over the network until somebody requests it, which is different from how your feed works which has an explicit store an forward system.

This isn't great because often your phone opens the app, posts the images, then you do something else. Apple will then kill the app in the background to save battery and memory. Unless somebody requested the image while you had the app open then it won't flow out over the network. It stays on your phone until you're running the app at the time somebody tries to view the image.

There are a few things we need to do to improve the way the images flow through the network. First we're switching from a polling model of connections to one where the connection stays open for bi-directional traffic. This will make images show up much faster. We do requests all blobs on our pub's to try and get them that way, but it doesn't always work. 

We've also looked at using something parallel to scuttlebutt for blobs like dat or ipfs, but we haven't gotten there yet.

A couple days ago #scuttlebutt was featured on #hackernews, a lot of [the discussion](https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=22909984) centered around the way the current legacy feed encoding format signs json and doesn't support edit, delete, and private groups. We're working on that. First Planetary supports a new format that encodes the feed using CBOR instead of json, we're calling it, [GabbyGrove](https://github.com/ssbc/ssb-spec-drafts/blob/master/drafts/draft-ssb-core-gabbygrove/00/draft-ssb-core-gabbygrove-00.md). Right now Planetary supports both the legacy format and the new ones, but we're still working on getting support in to the [node implementation of scuttlebutt](https://github.com/ssbc/). It's an open source project and the community would love contributions to fix things. 

In terms of privacy? Right now it's not fantastic once you're on the network most of the posts are public. We're working on [private groups](https://github.com/ssbc/private-groups-spec). That's what's really needed for planetary and scuttlebutt to live up to the promise of a fully decentralized open privacy aware social media protocol.

Hey [@Kenzo](@twmwAnbTCZjvYxPCFV6FW9QGeqVLFJiP6MDjML49aSY=.ed25519) ,

So [private messages in scuttlebutt](https://handbook.scuttlebutt.nz/concepts/private-message) are written to your log in something called a private box. The first message in the box is the box key encrypted once for each participant. Then each person who has access to the box uses the new keypair to write messages on the private thread. The messages themselves are encrypted and posted on each person's log. 

When your client gets an encrypted message it tries to decrypt it with it's keys. If it succeeds then you know it was for you. If you can't read it then it wasn't for you. This way you might know that your peer is writing private messages but not who they're communicating with. I'd say it's ok but not perfect metadata privacy. 

The encrypted messages do propagate across the peer to peer network but only the recipients can read them.

#### Planetary Update

We've released an updated version of [planetary](https://planetary.social/) with a bunch of updates under the hood. 
You can see the whole list of updates on our [changelog](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md).  We've also renewed commitment to answer questions about where we're going with the app by flushing out the [product roadmap](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/wiki/Product-Roadmap).

The updates in of the bot, threads for syncing data, and db for loading data has made the user experience much better. It gets rid of the loading and processing message delays that we'd been dealing with. The work [@cryptix](@uOReuhnb9+mPi5RnTbKMKRr3r87cK+aOg8lFXV/SBPU=.ed25519) has been doing on [go-ssb](https://github.com/cryptoscope/ssb) has been really promising and there's [more to come](%WPL1cXIi2eywXOWAnADzLFxmRul9JFA8wRAB8v/0nrI=.sha256). 

## [0.9.21] - 2020-05-10
### Added:
- New system for loading content so the UI updates faster and you can scroll back through history as far as you want.
- Changed the explore tab to show replies and new posts to help with discovering new content.

### Fixed:
- Fix bug where if you had more than 50 follows you wouldn't see new follows in your notifications tab.
- Changed Mixpanel actions to log user navigation through the app instead of just bot behavior. 
- Attaching GoBot logs to Share logs in Debug, to Bugsnag crash reports and to Zendesk tickets.
- Fix bug in background sync on notification of new content. 

## [0.9.21] - 2020-04-30
### Added
- All new Explore tab that shows posts from your greater network.
- New sync/refresh strategy that should be better at having your feed up to date.
Welcome [@PeterMartigny](@HehT6uUWMppRLf90zqa6utBOVJ0Kn/ILTs1FQF/Caoo=.ed25519) we're glad to have you. It's a beta product, but we've got grand dreams.
Yep, in theory the app should be much faster than centralized systems because all the data is local. Reality sometimes doesn't conform to theory, but we're working on bending reality to our will.

### Planetary Release 0.9.23

This release is mostly a refactor of the peer to peer bot. If you're not seeing new data, pull to refresh multiple times to catch up. New data does not show up unless you pull to refresh, it's a bug we're working on. We added display of likes which are done with other scuttlebutt clients. 

Added:
* Updated tab bar icon assets
* Adding localization for Castilian Spanish
* Add Uruguayan and Argentinian Rioplatenses localizations
* Add basic support for UI Tests
* Add support for displaying likes
* Displaying Pub Names


Fixed:
* Fixed dark mode icons
* Fixed bug with background sync on new notifications
* Optimize onboarding sync and refresh
* Clean up analytics for optional mixpanel metrics
* Change DBTests so that take into account likes
* rework bot.login & logout > login flow
* add timestamp to gobot logging
* fix timestamp setup on log files
* make timestamp swift-like but it's still UTC
* support re-syncing of existing key-pair
* re-do failed login dialog
* re-work restart on bot.login failure
* update english error text
* fixing it so the reply count includes likes
* fix closing of contacts index
* stop open connections during fsck
* reduce number of sync connections
* gobot: start in the background
* gobot.login: refactor defer->completion flow

We welcome [help translating](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/tree/master/Source/Localization) the app in to more than just English and dialects of Spanish.

### Planetary Release 0.9.24

This is mostly a bug fix [release](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/releases/tag/0.9.24) to get rid of the rebuilding database step / bug. We've changed explore so it only shows you posts by people who are followed by people you follow.  We added web hosting of your content for sharing and discovery through planetary.link.


#### Added:
* changing explore so it only shows you people you're not following
* enable universal links for planetary.link

#### Fixed:
* no more rebuilding db, now it just overwrites duplicate data
* skip nulled messages in private log
* scroll top when tapping on the explore icon
* only display blobs which are images
* fall back to blobs hosted by planetary if muxrpc fails to get them over ssb

## Planetary Release [0.9.25](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/releases/tag/0.9.25)

We've cleaned up how we load images from peers, we've provided notification of when to pull to refresh because you've got new posts, and we've expanded who you can see in the directory. Not a huge release, but it makes things better. 


## Added:
- New posts - Pull to refresh notification
- Directory includes all the people in your follow network, not just planetary users
- Note on posts reminding users they can use markdown

## Fixed: 
- Upper left profile avatar now shows your profile avatar
- Duplicate message bug fixed.

Yep, [@Kenzo](@twmwAnbTCZjvYxPCFV6FW9QGeqVLFJiP6MDjML49aSY=.ed25519), high on our list is to change the way we store and display notifications, there's a bunch of things like likes on your posts, replies to a thread you started, replies to a thread you participated in, etc.. which need to be added there.

### Planetary Release  0.9.27
This adds some social media niceness around liking posts and sharing them to other services. The big change is for new users, some feed data is bundled in the app so it's usable immediately while it starts syncing with the network. 

#### Added: 
* Preloading some feed content for faster first time user experience.
* Liking posts! You can now do this.
* Social media sharing of posts and users profiles. 

#### Fixed:
* Improved Image Loading

### Planetary Release 0.9.27 (220)

This is a bug fix [release](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/releases) as we noticed that we were getting a number of crashes with 0.9.26 (217). This release also has a few cosmetic updates around loading blobs and providing content for new users when they first sign up. 

Added:
* We preload some feeds when onboarding so you don’t have to wait to see something.
* Blob loading spinner.
* Load blobs from cloud as fallback.

Fixed:
* Crashes in the directory.
* Crashes when updating the database.

And for folks who want to chat with the planetary team, we've created [a matrix chat room](https://matrix.to/#/!kgNNtLPmJqLtvGAGKR:matrix.org/$mzSsXpZy-UVjx3wnnYW4_wCv9zxWVPZAdTg2TupvP04?via=matrix.org).

#### Moderation & Community Self Governance

Planetary is built on the idea that digital communities are governed best by their own communities. The creators of the platform shouldn't be expected to take on the impossible task of regulating speech, values, and norms. 

A really great model for this is emerging in the #scuttlebutt protocol we're using for #planetary. [@Tim Robinson](@Py8stqMfjhdc4Ln92R4Lg+3jITszP94G3P5BNuH+lWY=.ed25519) who wrote up [A TRUST AND MODERATION SYSTEM FOR THE DECENTRALIZED WEB](https://adecentralizedworld.com/2020/06/a-trust-and-moderation-system-for-the-decentralized-web/). A decentralized system in and of itself is not better. It'll be messy, but it will have the advantage of working the way most human systems worked. There will be conflict and politics. But what this system does is give us the fundamental building blocks of a well governed commons to build our digital publics.

Hey [@jalexandratos](@+UFt1L9I80Q05DWFzRQZCIkSpzKLPTk3NeurEvwnCs0=.ed25519) & [@jalexandratos](@+UFt1L9I80Q05DWFzRQZCIkSpzKLPTk3NeurEvwnCs0=.ed25519) we're having some bugs with scheduling which pubs to connect. We use the #go-ssb implementation and it schedules differently than the js one. Our hope is the next release will fix this problem.

Yeah [@Tanuva](@wUkBCZBKHHQHHMZU2Fnj/BXwq8DEn32TeMVbaId+he4=.ed25519) it's really a problem which we're working on. Both we don't want to show you the notification until you can see it and we want to make them show up much faster.

At Planetary we believe in controlling your data and running your own infrastructure. [@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519) has done a ton of [work on the go-ssb](%UhK5bsuXrhuyYMNNSbEzW0Rw+MkWWdIKa1dVf0Rtqr4=.sha256). We're using it both in the app and on our cloud pubs to provide connectivity.  Now we've got the [mooncake pub](%qfqUf3+dLfmyFC9kZUIA99E5s5qch/VSJBP9mSHP588=.sha256) by [月光虹](@g6c1/Zywct6TZsff4z26g24ax5HYmGvun7e3qT/yIPg=.ed25519). It's a project to make it easy to setup and run pub's using #go-ssb on micro servers.
Ghost has some good tools for self hosted email / blog / website services.

### Planetary Release [0.9.28](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/releases/tag/0.9.28)

Big release of Planetary. [@Sebastian Heit](@a+PqJTSfL3nZjmU5/MNWuAFRqHQAZgb5qQ0jGlxurPE=.ed25519) redesigned the explore tab in the app to make it easier to see discover new posts from your extended network.  We added the ability to see when the last sync with peers happened and trigger a new sync. We also noticed that our UI for liking was a 👍 but now it's a heart ❤️. Full emoji reactions is still on the roadmap. 

![Screen Shot 2020-06-30 at 1.00.19 PM.png](&8FGPJStREZduN5E+BEEzHW5e/Vfca0BQzyXI434garw=.sha256)
![Screen Shot 2020-06-30 at 1.01.05 PM.png](&LyC+o07U+w3cwUGkCQkev9nTQ3zOjM6NxbApBEYABpo=.sha256)

[@cryptix](@p13zSAiOpguI9nsawkGijsnMfWmFd5rlUNpzekEE+vI=.ed25519) did [a bunch of work](%UhK5bsuXrhuyYMNNSbEzW0Rw+MkWWdIKa1dVf0Rtqr4=.sha256) on #go-ssb to add support for deletes to the core library. When you block somebody it now deletes that content from your device. We've started getting contributions from [@月光虹](@g6c1/Zywct6TZsff4z26g24ax5HYmGvun7e3qT/yIPg=.ed25519) on the go code base as well, they released an updated set of docs for [mooncake](%qfqUf3+dLfmyFC9kZUIA99E5s5qch/VSJBP9mSHP588=.sha256), a scuttlebutt pub using the go code base. Tweaks to the algorithm for choosing and reconnecting to pub's has really improved the user experience. 


#### Added:
• Explore content in the all new discover screen.
• Block users.
• Give hearts instead of liking a post.
• Tap the network status doodle to trigger a sync.

#### Fixed:
• Issues some users where having syncing the latest posts.  
• Improved request and loading of blobs.

#### Planetary Release 0.9.29 (225)

Not a huge release, we're mostly working on tracking down why syncs aren't happening for some users. We also added the ability to search following / followers lists by name or identity.

In other news, [@cblgh](@C6fAmdXgqTDbmZGAohUaYuyKdz3m6GBoLLtml3fUn+o=.ed25519) finished up their [masters thesis](https://cblgh.org/articles/trustnet.html) on applying TrustNet calculations for content moderation and to combat abuse and harassment in a decentralized way. 

Added:
- Followers are sorted by name
- You can now search among your followers by name or identity

Fixed:
- Tooling and statistics to figure out why some users aren't seeing updates and syncs.

I do get the two confused, but part of what we're trying to figure out is planetary as an offline first, potentially end to end encrypted platform useful in repressive environments. I think we need to update the underlying protocols, but it's something we'd like to be good at.

Interested in a call?
We did look at reddit as one of the example apps when we were designing planetary.  It's because i think that reddit allows a similar mix of short and long form content and nested comments.

### Planetary Release 0.9.29 (226)

Big changes in notifications. They work as you’d expect now. We had a bug where you’d get notifications when our pub saw something for you and not when your phone found new notifications for you. This has been fixed and now notifications can work without any need for planetary servers and the content is always available when the notification is displayed.

We’ve also added an option to set if you want your content to be visible through the web gateways like [planetary.link](https://planetary.link) and [viewer.scuttlebot.io](https://viewer.scuttlebot.io/).


#### Added
* Create notifications locally
* Display notification in Notification Center
* Notify about replies to posts user replied to
* Add public web hosting option in Settings
* Add Share Public Identifier option

The scheduler for choosing what pubs to connect to is making really poor choices. If you redeem an invite to a pub it'll use that more often. The next release we've completely rewritten the scheduler and it should work much better.

### Planetary Release 0.9.30

This latest release is all about content updating and syncing. The planetary app was not prioritizing syncing with pubs based on their reliability and this was causing a user experience where content might not update for a while. With this release we've both tweaked the relay pubs we're running and how we prioritize connections. This is part of a larger effort to update and [release code](https://github.com/planetary-social/) for a faster & more efficient set of peer to peer libraries. 

#### Changelog:
* Subscribe to new pubs
* Create a Pubs table
* Remove old pubs
* Always check the redeemed pubs before syncing
* Refactor operations during onboarding
* Create Mission Control Center to manage missions
* Add logging and clean tests
* Fix Unit Tests
* Update Github Actions config file

As always, if you're using Planetary, and you want to upgrade, go in to the apple TestFlight app to update things.

Yeah, so [@wakest](@89cCJmBp7Oq/JewbOTjUQtXxB6QsHsCNVrCr5OIU5mU=.ed25519) the syncing works much better now. This was in a big shift in [how we managed pubs and connections](https://github.com/planetary-social/planetary-ios/commit/a216cdf9eae3faa87d2f2891992e0626a383fcef). We added new pubs to the planetary network, switched to using invites instead of a followback api, so you don't need an internet connection, and created a pubs table in the local db which tracks invites, and some connection status history. 

The next release will include our rewrite of [peer discovery](https://github.com/planetary-social/swift-peer-discovery) and [gossip](https://github.com/planetary-social/swift-gossip) putting it in the swift code. There's some apple libraries for mesh networking which meant we needed to do it in swift, or it was easier anyway. We also found that just debugging between go and swift was tricky. So the more network stuff we needed to work on, the easier it was to do in swift. Documentation will come for these libraries as well as packaging so people can use them in their own projects.
Nice! Have you seen the new documentary [The Long Way Up](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long_Way_Up)  about riding from Tierra del Fuego in Argentina all the way to LA on electric bikes?

New Design! We've updated the design and colors of Planetary from pinkish red to purple. We've also fixed links to messages in content and notifications.

content.title: movement + meditation
content.description:
Free contemplative yoga + simple meditation for one hour every Friday morning at [Woodbine.nyc](http://woodbine.nyc). The intention of this class is to address many of the body and mind patterns we fall into by accident, especially working on computers or phones: hunched shoulders, curled spines, achy hips and constantly-chattering thought spirals. 

We will be standing and sitting in chairs, but will not go on the floor, so you do not need to bring a yoga mat. Wear anything you find comfortable bending over in. Tea will be provided. <3

content.title: Art~Hack WLG: August 16th
content.description:
Every Thursday, everyone is invited to meet at Enspiral Dev Academy (275 Cuba St. Second Floor) for a few hours of coding and music-making and any other tech-inclined arts and dreams that you can carry with you to the venue. One of my favorite things about this event is that it is inherently social, but also has tinges of a study hall - there is no need to come with refined skills, and there's always a friend (known or new) to talk about your project with and ask questions if needed.

This week we'll have another pleasant yoga session from 6-7PM, so you can warm up your body + mind before hackin'. Mats are provided, and wear something comfortable if you want to participate. Art~Hack itself runs from 6-11 PM.  BYOB! All are welcome! <3

[60 minute Kundalini yoga classes every week, online!](https://angblev.com/yoga/live) This month we've been working with the theme of procrastination + follow through. Come travel through the internal cosmos with us :)

There are no webcams in this class, bc instead we'll go through a yoga set I made as a website (using pollen!) and drew all the images for. The class won't be recorded, but you have the website to reference whenever you like! (Or, you usually do: this kriya ain't up yet because I'm putting out an entirely new website later today. Yeehaw!)

No special equipment necessary, just somewhere 
you feel comfortable rolling around on the floor. 🌟 donation/free ✨
